												I was really surprised by this game, Signal Studios and Krome Studios have definitely stepped up the offering from previous games. I love the maps, lots of foliage and open terrain, with beautifully designed structures. The eight armies all have something different and unique to offer, the game IMO is a good complement to owners of Toy Soldiers Complete, love the new look and design. I have this game for PS4 and PC, PS4 is more colorful and cartoonish to a degree than the PC version, though on a good rig, PC looks more intricate and detailed, it's a preference thing, some will like one version over the other. The graphics and unit designs in this game are infinitely better than previous offerings of Toy Soldiers games, by far, this is the best looking game in the series to date. Sound effects on headphones is great, and when playing on my Logitech Z-5500s, some of the anti-personnel weapons should be more defined and powerful sounding, though they still sound great.The progression map and unlock of unique units and traits is a great approach, you can pick a faction and level it up throughout an open progression campaign map, nice touch. Overall, I highly recommend this game, seeing the Joes, He-Man and others battle it out on beautifully designed maps and levels is a joyous sight to be had. Hope to see more content added to this game in the future, want more of it, it's that good!I've played mostly on console, just picked up the PC version, playing on an i7-920 stock, Gigabyte G1 970 at 2560x1440 all video card settings and in game maxed with zero issues so far, Windows 10 OS. Of note, some of the troops on the turrets do odd things I've noticed, I'm mostly using Phantom and I noticed some of the individual troops on your turrets are not even firing at the enemy, they are just randomly firing off into nowhere, a little disconcerting, more of an immersion breaker, than anything else. Another thing, the difficulty spikes up tremendously at times, especially with bosses, so be prepared.

												I was very dubious about this game given the luke warm reception from reviews and let's play videos, not to mention the cheeky first day DLC which costs more than the game does, but eventually I caved into the nerdgasm induced by He-Man and G.I Joe armies... no homoerotic tone intended; I'm an 80's kid, had some of the toys and watched the cartoons.Anyway this is my review. I have almost 4 hours on this game at the time of reviewing so already I feel that I am in a better position to review this game than people who have 0.5 hours in it and such.First I downloaded. I was expecting Uplay but it hadn't been installed since my latest format, so I sat there for the better part of 30 minutes while it installed. Once it did I tried to login. It had been a while so I sat there thinking of the passwords I normally use but none were correct. I was then locked out of Uplay because I had tried to login too much. Not being given an option to do anything about it, and the password reset not working at all, I went onto the website to try to send a support ticket and guess what? That's right, I couldn't access the site because I was locked out. ♥♥♥♥ing hilarious right? In the end I had to call, yes, call Ubisoft and ask them to do something. The guy was helpful despite me remarking about how terrible Uplay is, he even said "We get a lot of complaints about Uplay." He couldn't insult the company that employed him of course, nor would I expect him to, but it was funny none the less. "Can I help you with anything else today?" He asked. "Yes, please tell your bosses that Uplay is a pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥and to please stop making us use it." I laughed, he laughed and in a diplomatic tone said "I will certainly pass that information over for you sir."I digress. The game! So first impressions; what a crappy port! The resolution works fine of course but the menu feels quite akward, almost as if the game just had mouse support slapped in with a bit of digital tape. Still, it's not horrendous.I watched a Let's play video earlier of a guy reviewing it and he hit the roof when he saw the shop with microtransactions. Erm, mate? You can grind that money and it's really effin easy too. So scratch that as a con off of your list if you are thinking about this game. Microtransactions are purely for impatient/lazy people. They are not necessary!The framerate. Yes most people have an opinion of how choppy it feels being locked at 30fps. Well I didn't, it felt fine to me even on full graphics. I'm not going to say that people who are going on about that are snobs or anything, but it's no where near as jumpy as they make out. If it is, I would maybe suggest that it's their rigs...maybe lacking in ram or up to date drivers, I don't know. Update: Been playing for 11 hours now so far and not had a single problem with framerate. Just a bunch of snobs complaining about something which isn't even noticable then.I do have a couple of problems with the performance though: you can't alt+tab. Well you can, but if you do, the resolution will reset to default (1280x768 iirc). In this day and age, inexcusable. Also when I was doing the tutorial I was given these TINY icons on the screen telling me what key to press; so tiny that I couldn't see what it said. I'm assuming this is because the resolution was never meant to go that high on consoles and they just didn't bother to make the icons bigger to compensate... but otherwise the resolution is fine.So the gameplay. It's a tower defence game with toys. It's actually a lot of fun. The graphics are a little dated looking and the controls quite basic, but that's by no means a horrible thing. The gameplay is alot of fun. You can unlock upgrades and each army feels quite unique if not in it's options but in it's feel. Campaign seems only good if you want to unlock stuff but gets quite annoying later on. The weekly thing seems quite fun. I want to try co-op when I convince my friends to get it, but for now my experience is in single player.The controls are fine for the most part, but now and again you are given control of a map defined flying unit.... the controls are screwed for those and that needs to be fixed asap.It's a good game, despite it's shortcomings. I have read a post from a developer on another review saying how they are looking into the framerate cap, so they at least haven't given up on it. A few fixes here and there and it will be great. It's really up to you if you want to pay 25 pounds (or $30, whichever currency you use) for everything; You only really get half a game if you get the vanilla and not the hall of fame edition. It's really cheeky of them to do that but I still think this game is worth that price: providing they add some general fixes to make the game more PC friendly. The only real gripe is with Uplay. I hate it, it doesn't work well, slow, and it's just more unnecessary processing power with everything else I'm running

												Introduction:    I have played the other two Toy Soldier game(Xbox) and enjoyed them a lot. They were very close to perfect and the second one was a clear step forward for the series. Toy Soldier War Chest falls shorter than either of those games to perfection and I feel it doesn’t grow the series at all. General Thoughts:     War Chest is a lot of fun it uses the formula that the other two games built but does do all that much different from the other two games. The hero mechanic has been expanded where you have a kill-streak like bar. As you get more kills in the turret that you’re using the bar will go up unlocking hero, vehicle, and then super weapon for you to use. Each race has unique turrets animations, models and has some slight differences in rate of fire and range. Heroes have unique and fun weapons but the dlc heroes don’t have as many as the base game heroes when it comes to weapons. Heroes also can’t jump this is a flaw and really should have been added. Other than those features the game plays the same as the other to titles in the franchise. It has weekly invasions(challenges) which are fun and will expand the gameplay slightly.The Bad:      Having a sequel that doesn’t grow the franchise isn’t always bad if they improve what’s there. War Chest doesn’t, it plays like the other two but now heroes are harder to control. It’s annoying but not 100% bad when it comes to the hero’s controls although I would highly recommend a controller. The other two toy soldier’s games had a unique fun war theme with them. War Chest is fun but that war theme is no longer there really, so if you wanted that feeling you won’t find it here. There is a in game shop. This does have micro transactions, but you can unlock anything with coins you will earn in the game. You get the coins fairly and I feel they added just of those that are impatience with getting unlocks.The Good:     It plays as well as the other two games(excluding heroes) with fun level design that will give you a challenge. It’s a fun game and you’re looking for a good tower defense game with some third-person components you will find it here. The upgrading for turrents have been sighlty improved now you can upgrade different parts individually. (range,damage,armor)The Meh:     Uplay, it’s here, it isn’t as bad as I thought it would be. It took only about 5 minutes to set up and I have had no problem with it when in game. It does take a couple extra minutes for the game to start though. The menu is bare bones its only what you really need and not much else.Final thoughts:     Even with its flaws it’s a fun and good game in the series. I would recommend it to you on sale. If you like tower defense games and need something to scratch that itch this will do it for you.

												Toy Soldiers War Chest is made by Signal Studios and published by Ubisoft; this means it uses UPlay, so if you have some kind of aversion to UPlay, be advised. The game also features a 60FPS cap because the game's physics are calculated via the frame rate.TSWC comes with 4 armies to play as by default:- Kaiser (WWI German Empire)- Phantom (Sci-Fi Space Marines)- Starbright (Fantasy Girls' Toys)- Dark Lord (DnD-esque RPG themed set)In addition, there is day-one DLC that adds up to four more armies:- GIJoe (1980s)- Cobra (1980s)- He-Man (1980s)- Assassin's CreedSignal really dropped the ball by not including Skeletor as a faction and instead including Assassin's Creed. Although I am sure the inclusion of the well-known Ubisoft franchise was purely a contractual obligation and I understand it.The game also features shortcut-micro transactions. While these optional payments may save you an hour or two of game play earning the in-game coins used to unlock turret upgrades, I cannot say it's worth it.The game play is much more solid than Signal's previous game, Toy Soldier: Cold War. Cold War is bundled with the original Toy Soldiers game in a port made by Chrome Studios; Signal had nothing to do with porting Complete to PC, so keep that in mind.Why is the game play better than TS:C? Let's start with the biggest game changer: The turret upgrades.In previous Toy Soldiers games, the turrets had only a level-1-2-3 upgrading system. In TS:WC the turrets now have three trees to upgrade: Attack, Defense, and Range. This allows the upgrades to be diversified. There are several types of turrets as well. These are based on the GIJoe army, but the turrets have the same archetypes across all 8 armies:- Anti-Infantry- Anti-Vehicle- Anti-Air- ArtilleryThe game features two different building pads, large and small. AA and artillery turrets can only be built on large pads, while anti-troop and anti-vehicle turrets can be built on any platform.The game also features a 'hero character' system which can be a game changing aspect.For instance, in the GI Joe set, after filling the kill points bar up to a certain level, you unlock the ability to play as the GI Joe character Duke, complete with screw holes and action figure joints. Duke has a few weapons, like an automatic rifle, a rocket launcher, and grenades. However, filling the bar more without using Duke will allow you to use the Dragonfly attack helicopter, which has machine guns and missile launchers. Filling the bar all the way allows you to call in a Skystriker bombing run. All the armies have their own unique hero units; Cobra has Cobra Commander and He-Man has the titular hero, and such.However, these hero units rely on batteries to use. The character and mid-tier vehicle use battery power, and the bar depletes over time. You can fill the bar by picking up the batteries scattered across the level, but these batteries are finite, leading to you being mostly dependent on your gun turrets. This is a smart move from a design perspective as the hero units can pretty much face roll all enemies on the playing field.So the turrets; at first, all the upgrades are locked. The first few levels as you first begin will be slightly challenging without the needed coins to unlock the upgrades. However, you earn a very large sum of coins in each level which can unlock one or two upgrades per-successful level completion, which means unlocking all the upgrades is just a matter of maybe an hour or two.The game measures your progress in 3 area, on a scale of bronze, silver, gold, platinum:- Aggression- Profits- Toybox healthAggression is how long you wait between waves. In order to obtain the platinum medal for aggression, you must skip the wave wait times on every wave almost instantly. Profits are how much resources/money you have leftover at the end of the level. This is also easy to get if you are frugal and don't mindlessly upgrade turrets. You can also earn more credits back by selling anti-air turrets after the final aircraft waves have finished.Toy box health is how much of the health of your base, or 'toy box' has left. In order to make platinum, the toy box MUST end the game with 100% health. In several levels, there are multiple toy boxes, which means you must cover all angles of attack.The main game's campaign does not feature the DLC armies; however, at certain points after playing through the campaign, you will unlock 'survival' levels that are based on the DLC armies. These survival levels are never-ending waves of enemies with increasing numbers. Even with a perfect defence, the turrets will take damage over time and will require repairs or they will be destroyed. It's a war of attrition, and it goes on as long as you are willing to put up a fight.- GI Joe Survival- Cobra Survival- He-Man Survival- Assassin's Creed SurvivalThe game has a randomly chosen 'Weekly War' campaign that changes each week. The war includes several levels where you fight one random army in the game and by beating the campaign you unlock coins and upgrade boxes for the turrets.The game has multiplayer listed on the store, but I haven't tried it, and as such I cannot pass judgement on the multiplayer aspect.Overall, if you like 1980s GI Joe or He-Man, and you want to have an afternoon of fun rolling in nostalgia, I'd give it a try. The upside of UPlay is that if you unlock the UPlay achievements, you earn UPlay credits which can unlock cosmetic skins for the default four armies, as well as the soundtrack and backgrounds.If you have any concerns or questions about the game you want to know before buying it, leave a comment and I will answer it and append your answer to my review.

												It's a really fun game. There are some bugs and things to iron out, but I don't regret my purchase one bit.A lot of lemmings are throwing around a bunch of entitled gamer cliches to disparage the game, but let's look at the complaints: 30fps lock.So what? This isn't CS or some other twitch shooter. The game looks good and plays smoothly. Day 1 DLC.Look, I think there is something wrong with forcing people to pay for a map or weapon pack Day 1. That stuff should be packaged in with the base game. But that's not really what's going on here. They released a very cheap game ($15) and are simply asking you to pay a little extra money if you want to play licensed IPs such as GI-JOE and He-Man. Being able to play with classic IPs is one of the main attractions of the game, and you can't do that without paying for the IPs. That costs money, which has to come from somewhere. Either play the base game with in-house IPs or pony up and pay an extra $15–not an exorbitant price at all–to play with licensed IPs. Seems fair.  Microtransactions.I haven't found anything in the game that can't be purchased with tokens that you gain by simply playing the game. The game isn't P2W; it just gives you an option to save time by purchasing rather than farming tokens. You're not forced into microtransactions, and microtransactions allow the game to be released at a lower price point. It's a win-win: People can pay money to accelerate token accrual and people who don't purchase tokens benefit from a cheaper game.TL;DR: The game is fun, and people are getting their panties in a bunch for no reason.

												I was a big fan of the previous titles in the series, even though I have been anxiously awaiting numerous updates for the complete edition, but now with seeing this title I guess I can understand why it's taken them so long. The game is tower defense with heavy empahsis on action and actually controlling the towers to mow down the incoming hordes. You build in limited places, upgrade and control the towers at your pleasure.  So how does this compare to the previous Toy Soldiers...1. Obvious one here. Instead of just 'realistic' toy soldiers you do battle with different toy sets. One of the charms of the first game for me was the existential battle of fighting another army in a child like, mass destruction/killing for fun sort of way. With the fantasy elements obviously that dynamic is a little different. 2. Unlike the first game where you progress through stages to unlock upgrades for the overall towers, here you unlock different indivdual tower elements (range,power, etc) for the towerswith coins or random drops at the end of the level. This means a lot of grinding which was present in the previous games as well. But now with 7 or whatever sets of characters, that's a lot of playing maps over and over. And again although they are asthetically very different, as of now I don't see much variation in the actual functionality of the towers. 3. Every time you level up your different toy sets, you recieve these things that look like pogs. They are the individual upgrades for the turrets. You can also purchase boxes of the random upgrades as well. 3. There is a new weekly challenge mode. That's cool and helps with the grinding aspect. 4. Day one DLC. Yeah pretty lame. Be aware that even though the DLC packs are for Heman,♥♥♥♥♥Creed and whatever...Those character sets are available to play in the vanilla game. Purchasing the DLC packs just offers additonal toys as part of that set. For example with Masters of the Universe one of the things you get is that bad♥♥♥♥♥tiger thing for He Man to ride. So far I am enjoying it. I will update the review later once I have put in some more hours and (hopefully) get to play some online co-op.
